review_title: Great work environment and amazing location
pros: Tree campus with amazing SoCal weather. Co-workers dedicated to your professional development. Good Benefits
cons: Some offices on campus are extremely inaccessible to individuals with disabilities

pros: I have wonderful colleagues in the college
cons: The administrative turnover is worrisome, as is the fact that the institution seems to careen from financial crisis to financial crisis without ever finding a clear path forward. We are repeatedly asked to do 'more with less', and it is disheartening. Moreover, the university has treated its non-teaching staff poorly through the various crises.

review_title: Decent Benefits - Just be Prepared for Additional Responsibilities
pros: The reduced cost of housing is nice, and the stipend + single room are underrated benefits that really help the bank. Most of the coworkers are friendly, and RLH is doing a better job at checking in with everyone individually to make sure they're holding up well.
cons: Your success in the role will be largely determined by your team - if you have a team of people who like to cut corners, that makes scheduling programs and relying on their help quite difficult, in addition to decreasing the level of support you have.

review_title: Only good for VP level employees
pros: Students and co-workers are great
cons: So many lay offs and people quitting. Morale is low. President makes so much money, along with VPs while no one else can get a raise or promotion.

job_title: Associate Director of Marketing in Redlands, CA
pros: The outdoor campus environment is pretty; Small community college atmosphere; Tuition waiver for full-time employees
cons: The job market is insecure due to layoffs, pay cuts, and benefit reductions; Morale is extremely low among all employees; No opportunities for upward growth

pros: Collegiality was top notch, always willing to support peers.
cons: Leadership lead without regard, didn’t think of the impact decisions would have on students or faculty.

job_title: Graduate Peer Career Educator  in Redlands, CA
pros: Respect, healthy work culture, warmth, and communication
cons: Pay lower than a fast food employee, while having to have a Bachelor's degree and being a graduate student.

review_title: It’s not a good place if you’re looking for growth

cons: Not always super busy so some pay times are smaller

Pay is lower than average

pros: it is a beautiful place to work

pros: Beautiful campus, reasonably safe campus, students have a lot of entertainment, and sports to participate in.
cons: Struggling with leadership, technology and innovative ideas to keep operations running, Requires high level of patience to be employed here.

pros:

cons:

review_title: One of the Worst Places I’ve Ever Worked For
job_title: Marketing Communications Coordinator in Redlands, CA
pros: - own office. That’s about it.
cons:
This is quite possibly the worst place I have ever worked after 6 + years in my field. I was hired to work in Student Affairs, which was a mess when I got there and was still a mess when I left. 

The school is struggling to manage several things: its embarrassing parent Facebook 
 page where parents complain about literally everything under the sun, general admissions, standing out amongst the competition and providing a unique experience to students. 

The communication is this department is sub par at best. I never interacted with my boss, yet she would still scrutinize my work without giving me any indication as to what she wanted. It was almost as if she wanted me to read her mind and just know what she expected. I was hired to spearhead communications efforts and make improvements, however Redlands is stuck in the mud when it comes to a new way of doing things. They want to stand out against top competitors, but doesn’t welcome new ideas or change.

This school is incredibly liberal and seeks to please every single student. There was a drastic meal plan change, and they let students come in and complain for over two hours on the issue over literally nothing. They want to be everything for everyone, but yet they still do a below average job. 

I could not reach my full potential in this position. I would 100% recommend not working here. This place is beyond dysfunctional. I was incredibly disappointed as I was told I would be in a collaborate, supportive environment and it turned out to be the exact opposite.

pros: Good learning experience for a graduate student
cons: Slightly hectic and disorganized at times

pros: Good experiences working for this employer
cons: Not consistent hours, but flexible shifts

pros: As an adjunct faculty member, I have found working for the University of Redlands be an excellent experience. I have the academic freedom I desire, students whose commitment and quality is generally higher than at other institutions in the area, and the privilege of working for an organization in possession of both strong roots in the community and a progressive approach to the Future.
cons: Covid-19 has presented challenges for all educational institutions, including perhaps especially private institutions of Higher Learning.

pros: You can get an education with them.
cons: Will demand more of you than what you are compensated for.

pros: amazing office culture and supportive staff
cons: As a student employee my hours were restricted to 10 a week

pros: Great bosses, nice work environment, beautiful campus
cons: Smaller campus makes it harder to promote

pros: friendly staff, great community, fulling job
cons: na na na na na

pros: Great place to work at

job_title: Event Services Manager in Redlands, CA
pros: flexible hours, nice campus, friendly staff
cons: The biggest con working at this campus was a frequent rotation in staff.

pros: welcoming community to work with
cons: Some of the duty hours can be weird

pros: Very liberal institution that is very inclusive and friendly to work for.  Located in Southern California the weather is great most all year long.  Located in Redlands, a great little town, also a nice place to live.
cons: The ITS department is a little behind the times, although they are making great improvements.  The pay is pretty bad, at least for me.  A lot of senior staff have left in the last couple years, most probably because of new leadership (President - not a bad thing) and non-competitive pay!  I am way underpaid for what I do in other similar institutions.

review_title: Think long and hard before you choose to work of them.
job_title: IT Department Worker in Redlands, CA
pros: Beautiful and well maintained campus with an interesting history. They do try do keep their computer hardware updated with timely refreshes. The pay is not fantastic  but after two years of working at the UoR you and your family can attend for free if you wish to.
cons: If you have worked out in the real corporate world then you will not be happy working at the UoR. They have a help desk software but do not really make use of it. Watch your back because not everyone who seems friendly actually is.

pros: I have a great team and I trust my supervisor as much as is possible for this being a business that doesn't allow a lot of transparency.
cons: Lack of transparency from upper administration, lack of willingness from president and cabinet to look at reform for students of color, "good ol' boys club", lack of organization and planning - often large decisions about employment are made last minute, with employees kept on tenterhooks for weeks.

job_title: Assistant Director for Enrollment in Redlands, CA
pros: Work with people who genuinely care about the students and employees, small company where you truly make an impact, generous vacation package, generous company paid 403B retirement plan, and great schedule! Lot's of career opportunities in the Enrollment Department.
cons: Health and dental benefits are sub-par, the pay is low (as stated by many), very behind with technology, marketing and online programs are virtually nonexistent, slow to make changes and does not solicit feedback from employee stakeholders before making changes.

pros:
-Very flexible with schedule
-Manageable 
-Supervision not needed
-Always have enough work to fill up hours
-Increases your hourly wage by 25c every third semester.
-Increases hourly wage according to the law (ex: my $8.75 pay became $10.75)
cons:
-Only limited to 10 hours per week, which is not enough to survive in college
-Would need a second to third job if paying for own expenses
-Starting hourly wage is way too low for college students. Some are only getting paid minimum wage for work requiring high professionalism/special skills. The highest pay I've heard was around $12. It's pretty insulting to know other schools--even community colleges--have higher starting rates, like $12-15! The university really needs to work on this.
-No mobility. If you move to a different department, you start over that department's minimum wage. I know from personal experience.

pros: Beautiful campus, small town community.
cons: I have had multiple paychecks missed, and once even had the amount withdrawn from my account rather than deposited. Finance department was more interested in going home on time than in resolving the issue. Reimbursements for work-related expenses have taken up to three months despite a 4-week turnaround policy, with no compensation for related interest charges on personal credit cards. Health benefits are terrible, and HR will only do what is absolutely legally required of it if pressured. Everyone acts very nice to outsiders and new people but stonewalls if something actually needs to be done. Administration chooses to look the other way when problems occur in order to avoid additional work. Pay is ridiculously low compared to local cost of living, and level of professionalism within the office environments is correspondingly low. Accepting a job here was the worst mistake of my career.

review_title: It seemed better than what it really is.
pros: Retirement contribution by university is 7% of your wages. Free tuition for those that would like to earn an BA or BS, and discount for those getting a MBA. Health plan not so good, they have blue cross ETNA.
cons: Salary is pretty low in some departments. Some departments  work harder and get very low pay, for example in grounds department the average worker makes about $14. Per hour. Health plan not so good, they have blue cross ETNA. Co-payments are $35. Management is not so great, neither smart or efficient, and many times bias.

review_title: Redlands has been a humbling and enlightening experience.
pros: The work has required that I learn new perspectives and skills, but has allowed me to work independently and in a team or structured environment.  They have allowed for my personality and career goals to shape which projects I take on and have provided support for my own goals.
cons: The hours were limited by my student employee status.  I would have preferred to have had at least 20 or 30 hours.

review_title: Don't work here, this job will put you 6 feet under quick!
job_title: IT Department Worker in Redlands, CA
pros: There are not too many responsibilities.  The work load is reasonable.
cons: Not much gets done.  Management comes down on employees who actually try to efficiently and competently do their jobs with strange new rules that employees should not be using normal tools to do the job, nor do what their job is supposed to accomplish like actually fixing computers instead of just recommending where else to take them.

review_title: Good benefits, environment but low pay
pros: U of R offers a very flexible and family friendly work atmosphere. The paid time off, sick pay and other benefits are much more generous than the general market offers.
cons: Average pay is 15 - 20% lower than state institutions and 10% lower than many private institutions. Although the work environment in generally cooperative and tolerant, it can be difficult as a person who is socially and religiously conservative.

review_title: Assistant Professor in the College of Arts and Sciences at the U. of Redlands
pros: The students are nice and friendly.
cons: The salaries are low and the position is extremely time-consuming and demanding. The university has few resources, despite the high tuition, and pressures professors to become overly involved in the personal lives of students to create a false impression that it is a caring institution with a strong commitment to personal attention. Nothing could be less true... This approach exhausts the best professors while creating unsustainable expectations among students.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Redlands, CA
pros: Flexible work-schedule, with tasks and assigned responsibilities directly related to my fields of study (GIS/Business), coupled with an emphasis in Ethics, which the University prides itself on upholding and teaching.
cons: Cannot think of any Cons, since the part-time work is paid at a competitive rate, and runs concurrent with my existing class schedules.

review_title: Lots of work for low pay
pros: Beautiful campus and great students. Decent benefits and retirement. Small campus.
cons: Organization is flawed though and there are way too many administrators than staff. Not open to new ideas and often grabbing at straws to try new things at the expense of staff. Tradition dictates actions and alienates some employees. Very cliquish and lots of nepotism.

review_title: A great environment for adjunct faculty
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Santa Ana, CA
pros: The University of Redlands School of Business is an excellent community of instructors and students. The pay is excellent and the students are motivated and intelligent.
cons: If you're new to adjunct teaching, be aware that you will spend a lot of time outside of class preparing for class and grading papers.

pros: Great students. Lots of great coworkers. Tuition remission/exchange benefits. Excellent retirement. Lots of vacation and sick time for administrative staff.
cons: Poor enrollment leading to constant layoffs and worry about layoffs. Secretive culture. Expensive benefits. Salaries far below market. Upper management is very set in their ways and unable to change and adapt which has really hurt the university. Extremely political environment. Terrible morale.

review_title: I had a wonderful experience working at this University.
pros: The best reasons to work here is that the faculty and staff treat you like family. Everyone truly cares about education at this institution.
cons: The pay is not very competitive unless you have been there a long time or are tenured (I assume).

pros: Great environment, everyone who works there really cares about what they are doing.
cons: Pay is low for the industry.  Difficult to find good housing in the area.

pros: Great work environment, friendly employees, the company gives a lot back to it's staff in terms of holiday parties and bonuses.
cons: Long work hours, can be fast paced, must be able to deal with students who can be very rude at times, management is controlling

pros: Nice looking campus, and it is close to downtown Redlands which was nice when you could actually take the time to get away (which was rare).
cons: Very cliquish - if you aren't in the club you'll never be happy there.  People who graduated from there and then went right to work there seem very very happy.  That wasn't me.

review_title: It was a great job to have as a student, flexible hours.
pros: Get to influence the future students at University of Redlands
cons: Not many opportunities for growth, the job can get tedious after a while. But still a great place to work and a good job.

pros: Many students, faculty, and staff are friendly and easy to work with. The University actually cares a lot about its students.
cons:
- Political correctness mar an otherwise a great university. 

- Corruption rampant in a department, where I am currently working for few years now.

review_title: Pays Better Than Most Work Study - Get Hired Early

cons: Some drama; people don't always get their shifts covered so it can be busy with few workers or slow with many workers

pros: High quality staff and professors.  A very professional university.  A real undiscovered gem.  Great place to work!  Highly recommended.

pros:
A placid work environment, great atmosphere and best of all, my coworkers were the best.
